#Text=Edward Squire
#Text=For the public servant in the colony of South Australia , see Edward Squire ( public servant ) .
#Text=Edward Squire ( died 1598 ) was an English scrivener and sailor , and an alleged conspirator against the life of Elizabeth I of England .
#Text=He was executed , after an investigation of a series of obscure circumstances led to conviction for his apparent attempts to poison Queen Elizabeth and Robert Devereux , 2nd Earl of Essex .
#Text=A long controversy on the truth of the matter then ensued .
#Text=Life
#Text=Originally he was a scrivener at Greenwich , where he married and had children .
#Text=He then obtained a post in Queen Elizabeth 's stables , but gave up his position to become a sailor .
#Text=In August 1595 he started with Sir Francis Drake on his last voyage to the West Indies , on board the Francis , a small barque .
#Text=Late in October the Francis separated from the rest of the fleet off Guadeloupe , and was captured by five Spanish ships .
#Text=Squire was taken prisoner to Seville in Spain .
#Text=Having been released on parole , he may have formed a plan for discovering Jesuit secrets by a pretended conversion .
#Text=By attacks on the Roman Catholics he got himself imprisoned , and then was sent for Richard Walpole , a brother of Henry Walpole , and close to Robert Parsons .
#Text=Walpole is alleged to have instigated him to assassinate the Earl of Essex and Queen Elizabeth .
#Text=In order to disarm suspicion , a pretext was found for having Squire tried as a Protestant by the Spanish Inquisition .
#Text=The plan was to poison the pommel of the queen 's saddle , for which Squire 's previous experience in the royal stables afforded him opportunities .
#Text=Squire was exchanged for some Spanish prisoners , and he arrived in England in June 1597 .
#Text=Late in that month he is said to have rubbed on the pommel of the queen 's saddle some of the poison with which Walpole had supplied him , but without any result .
#Text=A week or so later Squire , partly to escape detection and partly to make an attempt on Essex 's life , embarked on the Earl 's fleet then about to set out on the Islands Voyage .
#Text=Between Fayal and St. Michael 's he rubbed some poison on Essex 's chair , with equal lack of success .
#Text=Soon afterwards either Squire himself or the Jesuits , believing that Squire had played them false , informed the English government of these designs .
#Text=Early in the autumn of 1598 Squire was arrested , and on 9 November he was indicted for high treason .

#Text=Repeated examinations by Francis Bacon and others produced varying results ; at first he denied all knowledge of the plot ; then he confessed both Walpole 's machinations and his own attempts ; subsequently he retracted the admission of his own misdeeds , but finally he repeated his confession , perhaps under torture ; the official statement was that it was made ‘ without any rigour in the world . ’
#Text=He was condemned and on 23 November was hanged , drawn , and quartered at Tyburn , repudiating his former confessions .
#Text=A special order of prayer and thanksgiving was issued to celebrate the queen 's escape .
#Text=Controversy
#Text=Squire 's alleged treason was the subject of a literary war between the government and Roman Catholic apologists , and their respective versions differ in almost every detail .

#Text=The official account , attributed by James Spedding to Bacon and printed among his works , was written by someone who was either present at Squire 's examinations or had access to the official documents , which it closely follows .

#Text=It is dated 23 December 1598 , and was published as a ‘ Letter written out of England to an English Gentleman remaining at Padua , containing a true report of a strange conspiracie contrived betweene Edward Squire … and Richard Walpole , ’ London .
#Text=It was reprinted in George Carleton 's ‘ Thankfull Remembrance , ’ 1624 ; and again , in 1733 , as ‘ Authentic Memoirs of Father Richard Walpole , ’ London , 1733 .

#Text=A reply to the official story ( attributed to Walpole ) appeared as ‘ The Discoverie and Confutation of a Tragicall Fiction devysed and played by Edward Squyer , yeoman soldiar … wherein the argument and fable is that he should be sent out of Spain … but the meaning and moralization thereof was to make odious the Iesuites , and by them all catholiques .
#Text=Written … by M. A. Preest , that knew and dealt with Squyer in Spain , ’ 1599 .
#Text=Another reply , ‘ A Defence of the Catholyke Cause , ’ was composed the same year by Thomas Fitzherbert , but not printed until 1602 .
